questions.q: What is a common disadvantage of networking in terms of costs?
questions.explanation: Setting up a network requires significant upfront investment in hardware (routers, switches, cabling) and labor.

questions.q: Which of the following is a fundamental network classification based on geographical area coverage?
questions.explanation: While PAN and WAN are also geographical classifications, LAN is the most fundamental classification for local area coverage.

questions.q: What is the primary function of a server computer in a network?
questions.explanation: In a client-server model, the server's role is to serve requests and provide resources to the clients.
options: It requests services from client computers
It provides resources and services to client computers
It serves as a standalone workstation

questions.q: Which network topology connects each device to a single, central point?
questions.explanation: In a Star topology, all nodes are connected to a central hub or switch.

questions.q: Which OSI layer is responsible for translating data between formats used by different networking devices?
questions.explanation: The Presentation Layer (Layer 6) handles data encryption, compression, and translation.

questions.q: At which OSI layer does routing and forwarding of packets occur?
questions.explanation: The Network Layer (Layer 3) is responsible for logical addressing and routing packets.

questions.q: Which OSI layer establishes, manages, and terminates connections between applications?
questions.explanation: The Session Layer (Layer 5) manages the dialogues (sessions) between computers.

questions.q: At which OSI layer do switches operate to forward frames based on MAC addresses?
questions.explanation: Layer 2 switches use MAC addresses to forward data frames.

questions.q: Which Application Layer protocol is primarily used for transferring web pages and related files over the Internet?
questions.explanation: HTTP (Hypertext Transfer Protocol) is the foundation of data communication for the World Wide Web.

questions.q: Which protocol translates domain names into IP addresses to locate resources on the Internet?
questions.explanation: DNS (Domain Name System) acts like a phonebook for the internet.

questions.q: What protocol is commonly used for transferring files between a client and a server over a network?
questions.explanation: FTP stands for File Transfer Protocol.

questions.q: Which protocol dynamically assigns IP addresses to network devices?
questions.explanation: DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol) automates the assignment of IP addresses.

questions.q: Which protocol is used for sending email messages between servers?
questions.explanation: SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) is used for sending/pushing mail.

questions.q: Which command is used to display the IP configuration details of a Windows computer?
questions.explanation: The ipconfig command displays all current TCP/IP network configuration values.

questions.q: What does the 'ipconfig /renew' command do in Windows?
questions.explanation: The /renew switch sends a request to the DHCP server to update the current IP lease.
options: It renews the lease of the IP address from the DHCP server

questions.q: Which command provides information about active TCP connections, listening ports, and other network statistics on a Windows system?
questions.explanation: Netstat (network statistics) displays incoming and outgoing network connections.

questions.q: Which IP address class ranges from 1.0.0.0 to 126.255.255.255?
questions.explanation: Class A addresses use the first octet for the network ID (1-126).

questions.q: What is the maximum number of hosts per subnet with a subnet mask of 255.255.255.224?
questions.explanation: 224 in the last octet leaves 5 bits for hosts (2^5 = 32). Subtracting 2 for network and broadcast gives 30.

questions.q: What is the default subnet mask for a Class C network?
questions.explanation: Class C uses 24 bits for the network, represented as 255.255.255.0.

questions.q: Which of the following is an invalid IP address?
questions.explanation: Each octet in an IP address must be between 0 and 255. 256 is out of range.

questions.q: Which IP address is commonly utilized for loop-back testing and refers to the local host?
questions.explanation: The 127.x.x.x range is reserved for loopback; 127.0.0.1 is most commonly used.

questions.q: Why is 255.255.255.255 considered an invalid IP address for a host?
questions.explanation: 255.255.255.255 is the limited broadcast address for the current network.
options: It is a reserved broadcast address
It falls within the private address range

questions.q: Which IP address range cannot be used as part of a public IP address due to its private designation?
questions.explanation: All options listed are actually non-public, but 10.x.x.x is a primary RFC 1918 private range.

questions.q: Which networking device operates at both the Physical Layer (Layer 1) and the Data Link Layer (Layer 2) of the OSI model?
questions.explanation: Standard switches work at Layer 2 to handle frames, but involve Layer 1 for physical connectivity.

questions.q: In a TCP/IP network, what is the purpose of subnetting?
questions.explanation: Subnetting improves network performance and security by localizing traffic.
options: To establish a secure connection between two remote networks
To divide a large network into smaller, more manageable segments
To dynamically assign IP addresses to network devices
To facilitate communication between devices within the same LAN
